data.text: Contents
Introduction

It is absolutely essential that all communications with persons associated with a member of staff dying in post are conducted with sympathy, sensitivity and with the utmost dignity and respect. This policy sets out the process that needs to be followed when responding to the death of a staff member.
Scope
This policy applies to all employees of the Trust including medical and dental staff.
Definitions

table_items.text: Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust

A document rota co-ordinators/departments use for reporting absences such as sickness etc when staff are not on health roster. It is sent to the ESR team on a monthly basis so they can then log the information on the persons ESR record.

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive
The Chief Executive, as Accountable Officer, has overall responsibility for the Health, Safety and Welfare of employees. The implementation of this policy is one aspect of that management role.
Chief People and Organisational Development Director

The Chief People and Organisational Development Director is responsible for the implementation of the Policy across the organisation and will ensure that the policy is updated in line with all current and new legislation.
Employee Relations Department
The Employee Relations Department advises managers on the application of the policy and ensures that staff are supported following the death of a staff member.

Line Managers  Responsible for notifying the relevant leads such as the Chief Executive's Senior Executive Secretary (Chief of Staff) and Human Resources Business Partner that a death in service has occurred.
Will notify the Employee Relations Department of the death of the member of staff and ensure all the relevant paperwork is received and forwarded to the appropriate Human Resources Business Partner.

Ensures that appropriate support is in place for affected colleagues through the Employee Assistance Programme (EAP); Trauma Risk Management (TRIM) and Occupational Health) or Broomfield in house Psychological Therapy Service which may be contacted on 01245 514838 as required.
Ensures all calls and correspondence relating to the death in service are dealt with in a sensitive and confidential manner.
Draft correspondence of condolence and subsequent letters as outlined in the procedure.
Responds appropriately to the requests of the next of kin and organise tributes as appropriate.
Complete a termination/leaver's form and other forms as appropriate, for the deceased employee and forward to Workforce.
Decide how patients of the deceased should be informed where applicable.
Oversee the return of personal property and the collection of Trust property from the deceased member of staff's next of kin / estate.
Arrange for the removal of the deceased employee's details from all Directorate / team distribution lists.
Workforce Department
The Workforce ESR will liaise with the Trust payroll provider and the Pensions Agency, where applicable, and ensure the necessary documentation is received.
Procedure
The Line Manager should ensure that the information received in respect of the deceased is accurate/of bona fide origin. This information should be forwarded to Human Resources Business Partner.

In the event of Medical Certificate(s) not having been received to cover the immediate period prior to death; such certificates should not be requested from relatives as such a request may increase the trauma/grief to the family member/next of kin.
The line manager should notify the appropriate Human Resources Business Partner of the death of a staff member.

Payroll should be notified immediately by the line manager, as well as completion of an email to the e-rostering team to request that the deceased employee's name is removed from the e-roster system, this should happen automatically via the leavers form; however this must be emailed to ensure this takes place as soon as possible

If the Employee is in the pension scheme, then the Death in Service Notification Form (appendix 2) should be completed by the Human Resources Business Partner. The death certificate and marriage certificate, if applicable, will be required from the next of kin and to be sent to WorkforceESR by the Human Resources Business Partner.

Agreement should be reached as to who should send a letter/card expressing sympathy to family members i.e., from Trust Executive, Appendix 1 or Immediate Manager. This does not prevent close work colleagues from sending individual/collective cards/letters in the usual way.

A wreath (unless specifically not requested by family) should be sent by the Trust to the funeral and arrangements made for the Trust/Site/ Care Group/Unit/ Department to be represented at the funeral ceremony. This will be coded to the department's cost centre.

An employment termination form should be completed by the Line Manager and forwarded to WorkforceESR as soon as the information required is verified The termination date is recorded as the actual date of death along with documents listed below:
Copy of Death Certificate;
Name and address(es) of next of kin;
Details of outstanding annual leave and bank holidays;
Copy of positive return – duly completed (if the staff member is not on e- rostering).

In order that financial affairs of the deceased can be completed and arrangements made for payment to the deceased person's estate, all relevant documents will be forwarded by the Human Resources Business Partner to the Workforce Team who will provide the information to the Trust's payroll provider.
IT need to be advised to deactivate the employee's email and other associated electronic accounts.

With prior consent from the deceased employee's family, the communications team should be contacted to send an email to all staff informing them that an employee has passed away and details of the funeral and/or service to be held in the Hospital.

Following the death in service, there should be a respectable period of approximately 3 – 4 weeks, before the next of kin are contacted to arrange for Trust property to be returned, i.e. ID Badge, keys, mobile, bleep etc.

Discuss with team/ward if they would like to hold a service to mark the life of the employee who has sadly passed. Additionally emotional support for staff should be made available through occupational health and chaplaincy services
Death on duty/trust premises
Where there is a death of a staff member whilst they are actually on duty/Trust premises, arrangements will need to be made for medical examination/certificate of death in the normal way.
It is likely that the Trust facilities will be used in such situations i.e., Emergency Department, Mortuary etc.

Where death occurs in the close proximity of work colleagues, patients or the  general public, all attempts must be made to reassure all involved and to  organise/re-direct helpers and onlookers accordingly.

data.text: Incidents/accidents resulting in death at work or death resulting from suspicious circumstances must be reported to the appropriate Senior/Department Manager and Risk Manager (Site manager on call if out of hours) who will decide to contact family, Police or other relevant agencies. Incident/Accident reports must be completed as appropriate.
All efforts should be made to support and comfort anyone exposed to any of the above traumas.

Where sudden, tragic or distressing circumstances exist, staff may require  debriefing sessions and/or opportunities for more concentrated counselling.  Occupational Health and the Chaplaincy Service should be contacted for guidance and on-going support where this is indicated.

data.text: Friends and colleagues of the deceased employee may request that the Hospital Chaplain conducts a memorial service.
A Datix/Incident and Risk Reporting is required to be completed to review the circumstances of the death and any actions that may need to take place.
Chaplaincy support
Support provided by the chaplaincy service is detailed in appendix
Other special arrangements

In the event of a death in service, the Trust would wish to show support at a senior level to the next of kin and the deceased employee's colleagues. Where appropriate and agreed by the next of kin, it may be seen suitable that a Trust Director or Senior Manager represent the Trust at the deceased employee's funeral.

In agreement with the next of kin of the deceased employee, it may be appropriate for the Trust to facilitate a drive-by service for colleagues. This would be arranged by the line manager of the deceased employee and Human Resources Business Partner, ensuring liaison with all appropriate parties.

Death in service that has occurred as a result of COVID-19 during the course of an employee's work, should result in managers and the Human Resources Business Partner contacting the Bereavement Services. The Bereavement Services as part of the national COVID-19 reporting requirements to NHSE have the necessary information issued on the medical cause of death certificate to initiate claim for the NHS and Social care coronavirus life assurance scheme, Appendix
Other requests by the deceased's next of kin will also be considered by the Human Resources Business Partner and Line Manager.
Training requirement
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Employee Relations Team and Human Resources Business Partner.

Appendix 4: Chaplaincy support
The chaplaincy services provide support in a number of ways following the death of a member of staff.

As well as this being a very sad and painful time for everyone in your department, this can be a highly demanding time for managers. The Chaplaincy Team can offer support for you as you seek to honour the memory of your colleague and to help your staff express their sadness and grief. There is always a chaplain on call 24/7. The on-call chaplain can be contacted through the switchboard for any urgent issues. Please do not hesitate to get in touch if you would like a supportive conversation or a meeting.

The Chaplaincy Team is a multi-faith team and includes expertise in non-religious pastoral care. If in the first few hours or days after a death you would like one of the Chaplaincy Team to be present at a meeting in your department, please ask us. If you would like to meet in the Chapel or the Prayer Room, please do ask. The answer will be yes. Here there is the opportunity for people to light a candle, to write a prayer request on a leaf of the Prayer Tree or to sit and think.

If you would like to obtain a book of condolence so that bereaved colleagues can write a memory or a special message, the chaplains can help. They can also advise on the use of social media and on the different practices that are appropriate in different cultures. You may want to keep the book of condolences in the chapel so that staff can add their sentiments when they wish. We can also prepare a special table where photos and tokens of remembrance may be left.

The chaplain can organise a formal memorial service for your department - or a more informal time of recollection and thanksgiving for their life can be arranged. You may want to discuss where such an event should be held. Sometimes a service can be held on the day of the funeral so that your department who are unable to be there can have a special time to honour their colleague.

Alternatively, a service can be held at a later date and you may want to invite bereaved family and friends to this. You may like to do something in their memory, such as some fundraising or celebrating their life in a specific way. The chaplains can share with you some events that may be appropriate.

It is natural for you and your team to feel shock, anxiety and sadness after such bereavement. Other surprising feelings may arise, about ourselves and our loved ones, surrounding fragility and mortality which may be hard to bear. The chaplains are here to listen to you and anyone in your department who would like to talk. We can meet you at a time that is convenient for you.
